urn:contentItem:6GY2-8683-RRVV-92PN-00000-00The next generation: 30 inspiring people under 30 ready to serve and lead2025-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:39ZLexisNexisThe next generation: 30 inspiring people under 30 ready to serve and leadSophie Else

Business, politics, sport, community: future leaders shine.

The Border and North East region is home to an extraordinary group of young people making a real difference. From business and politics to the arts, sport and community service, these emerging leaders are shaping the future and inspiring others through their passion and dedication. The Border Mail's Sophie Else has compiled a list of 30 under the age of 30 who are already leaving their mark and making our region proud.

JARROD REDCLIFFE

Jarrod Redcliffe is serving up much more than sweet treats as the owner of Happy Cat Donuts, Wodonga's much-loved mobile doughnut van. Since taking over the business in November 2024, Mr Redcliffe has fulfilled a long-time dream of running his own food truck. Living with autism, he has bravely channelled his personal experience into the core mission of his business, establishing a workplace founded on inclusivity and accessibility and is now working on employing others who also have disabilities, something he is very proud to prioritise.

BHAKTA BAHADUR BHATTARAI

Bhakta Bahadur Bhattarai (Durga) is a community leader and registered nurse based in Wodonga, whose journey began in a Bhutanese refugee camp in Nepal before he migrated to Australia. In 2014, he founded Albury Wodonga Multicultural Community Events Inc (AWMCE). His leadership was demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic when he coordinated emergency food relief for over 450 households. The VIC Young Australian of the Year 2024 and La Trobe Young Achiever Award 2025 winner continues to inspire and help others who are in need.

ASHLEE FITZPATRICK

Ashlee Fitzpatrick is a trailblazer and councillor for the Wareena Ward in the Rural City of Wangaratta. First elected in 2017 at just 19 years old, she immediately made history as the youngest councillor in Wangaratta and the sole woman on the council. Now serving her third term, the Wangaratta native uses her platform to champion inclusivity, equity, and youth engagement. Her leadership journey started early, serving as a youth mayor before jumping into regional government. Alongside her work on portfolios that prioritise community wellbeing, youth, and families, Ms Fitzpatrick has volunteered with Zonta, Relay for Life, and Gateway Health.

NOAH TANZEN

Noah Tanzen is the youngest-ever elected councillor for the Alpine Shire , having been sworn in on November 14, 2024, at the age of 21. Raised in Mount Beauty, he has deep roots in the Kiewa Valley, where he works as an all-rounder at a brewery. A former Regional Young Achiever of the Year (Kiewa Valley) in 2022, he works toward a more resilient and inclusive Alpine Shire and uses open-minded approaches. Despite his focus on council, he maintains a burning ambition to become a career firefighter, while also holding a private pilot's licence and enjoying gliding in the Alps.

ILIYSH RETALLICK

Iilysh Retallick is one of Australia's most exciting new artists, launching her career as the runner-up on Australian Idol 2025. The singer, who hails from Culcairn, quickly established a stage presence by blending genres including classic rock, country, and pop. Her success was proven by her debut album, Idol Collection, which topped the iTunes charts and reached #5 on the ARIA albums chart. She has since transitioned to touring with her band and performing at smaller towns across the country in her Australian Idol-bought van.

JACK GREGORY

Jack Gregory is a 15-year-old country music singer, songwriter, and guitarist from Staghorn Flat. His musical journey began at the age of five when he received a guitar, and he started busking by the age of eight. Gregory has since performed at the Tamworth Country Music Festival. In 2024, he won the Australian Heritage Award at the CMAA Country Music Awards, which included a scholarship to attend the CMAA Junior Academy, formally recognising his talent and dedication to his craft.

ISAAC PRONK

Isaac Pronk is a highly skilled apprentice completing his Certificate III in Hairdressing at Wodonga TAFE. Known for his quirky, fun, and energetic personality, Mr Pronk secured a paid apprenticeship with Lavington salon Bohème Hair Artistry . Now in his fourth year, his commitment to excellence has been formally recognised: he won the Apprentice of the Year Award at Wodonga TAFE in 2024 and successfully represented the institution in the WorldSkills competition in 2025.

JYE MCBURNIE

Jye McBurnie is a dedicated champion for social justice and community safety, with a focus on addressing domestic and family violence. Mr McBurnie has already made significant contributions, earning him the honour of Young Citizen of the Year for the City of Wodonga in 2017. His influence extends to the federal level, where he has worked in a federal minister's office and a federal department, championing policies that support safe and secure environments for all Australians. He actively serves on advisory groups and panels at both the regional and state government levels.

HOPE CHATER

Hope Chater is a pioneering athlete who made local history as the recipient of the 2024 Young Achiever Award from Sport Albury Wodonga. As a kettlebell athlete, Ms Chater is the first competitor from the Border region in her sport to ever win the prestigious award. Her dedication and success extend globally, having competed in the Kettlebell World Championships. Beyond her competitive achievements, she shares her passion for fitness professionally within the community, cementing her status as a leading figure and showcasing the rising success of kettlebell athletics in the local sporting community.

MITCHELL CLARKE

Mitchell Clarke is a distinguished and pivotal figure in the Albury-Wodonga performing arts community, known for his exceptional talent and dedication to local theatre. He is a key contributor to the Albury Wodonga Theatre Company (AWTCo) and a frequent winner at the Georgy Awards , earning the Best Performer in a Musical award for both his portrayal of Patsy in Spamalot (2022) and Franki Valli in Jersey Boys (2021). Beyond the stage, Mitchell actively enriches the cultural fabric of the region, directing a sold-out fundraiser performance of Legally Blonde in 2024 and mentoring the next generation of performers.

EWAN NOONAN

Ewan Noonan is an industrious and selfless force in the community, balancing a full-time career as a broker with countless hours dedicated to fundraising initiatives and Rotary projects. He is a quiet contributor who applies his expertise and leadership to support emerging local talent through The Young Business Edge, helping shape the next generation. Ewan's generosity and tangible contributions, which also include support for Border sporting communities, make him an exceptional role model and a true asset to the Albury-Wodonga region.

INGRID MOL

Ingrid Mol is a proactive mental health advocate who has merged fashion with a good cause as the founder of L.A.Y.M. Clothing (Look After Your Mates). The brand is a direct support mechanism for men's mental health, as 50 per cent of its profits are donated to MensLine Australia. Ms Mol's initiative has already made a significant impact, having donated more than $8000 to the helpline, providing vital support for men facing mental health and personal crises. Her innovative approach highlights the critical role of community-based fundraising in promoting men's wellbeing.

ELI DAVERN

Eli Davern is a prominent young political figure from Albury known for his advocacy on climate action, mental health, and youth empowerment. At just 18 years old, Mr Davern made history as the Greens' youngest-ever federal candidate , contesting the seat of Farrer in the 2022 election and securing the highest-ever vote and swing for the party in that electorate. He followed this success by running for the state seat of Albury in 2023, focusing his platform on key regional issues like housing affordability and healthcare. His commitment to amplifying young voices in politics earned him recognition as the 2022 Young Citizen of the Year.

EVA MEDCRAFT

Eva Medcraft is the principal solicitor at Medcraft Legal, a criminal defence law firm based in Albury. After beginning her legal career in 2018 and graduating in 2020, Ms Medcraft was admitted to the Supreme Court of NSW in March 2021. Drawing on a diverse background that included commercial law and property development, she transitioned three years ago to criminal defence, where she is dedicated to ensuring the best possible outcomes for her clients. Her commitment to legal accessibility is further demonstrated by her role on the NSW Legal Aid panel. Beyond her practice, she actively supports the legal community by serving as the Regional president of the Albury and District Law Society.

DANIEL HATELEY

Daniel Hateley is a prominent mental health advocate and community leader, recently named Federation Council's 2025 Young Citizen of the Year. He is based in Corowa and is the founder of The Fight Is Real, a successful grassroots initiative. Through this platform, Mr Hateley has tirelessly worked to raise awareness and funds for mental health support, specifically targeting men in the Albury-Wodonga region and actively reducing the stigma surrounding mental illness.

KIRSTEN SARGEANT

Kirsten Sargeant is a marketing director and business leader, known as the founder of Frankk Marketing in Albury. She actively supports the next generation by providing mentorship, guidance, and work opportunities for emerging marketing professionals and designers. Her commitment extends to civic leadership, notably organising and hosting community events. Her impact on the region was formally recognised when she won the Young Business Leader at the 2024 Albury and Wodonga Business Awards.

LACHLAN MCINTYRE

Lachlan McIntyre is a classically trained tenor and performer from Albury whose talents span both the stage and public service. With a Bachelor of Music in classical voice and a Bachelor of Politics, Philosophy and Economics, Mr McIntyre has carved out a career that bridges the arts and politics. He has performed alongside some of Australia's most celebrated names, including Anthony Warlow, Marina Prior and David Hobson, and has taken on roles in productions such as Miss Saigon, Evita and Aladdin. Beyond the stage, he has also stepped into the political arena, working as an adviser to Federal MP Sussan Ley and contributing to public policy and community representation.

TILLY EDWARDS

Tilly Edwards is a dynamic professional blending creative arts with sharp business acumen, working as a wedding photographer and Dash Cakes' social media star/barista. With more than six years of experience, Ms Edwards has a wide skill set from marketing, event management, and modelling. She uses her expertise to help businesses, from start-ups to large operations, grow their brand, demonstrating her capability to deliver in high-intensity situations across any field.

SOPHIE HANRAHAN

Sophie Hanrahan is an unparalleled talent in the Ovens and Murray netball league, where the Corowa-Rutherglen star has cemented her legendary status. The 27-year-old Roos gun and dynamic goal defender, made league history this season by once again claiming the prestigious Toni Wilson Medal. This remarkable achievement sees her equal the record high of four medals, an honour she now shares with North Albury's Emily Browne, solidifying her position as one of the most dominant and consistent athletes in the league's history.

CHENIKA LEVETT

Chenika Levett is a force for change in youth development, serving as a W.I.S.E. Youth Worker focused on re-engaging local youth. Through expert coaching and mentoring, Ms Levett works specifically with disengaged school-aged individuals, equipping them with essential life and professional skills. Her commitment ensures these young people are empowered to build confidence, gain independence, and successfully transition into the workforce, cementing her role as a vital mentor in the community.

EVA GEERLING

Eva Geerling is an inspiring young voice in children's literature, whose self-published picture books are making an "impressionable impact" on young readers. The former Trinity Anglican College student turned her love of drawing into a unique platform, releasing books like Precious One that focus on joy and Christian faith. This foundation comes naturally, as her parents are former pastors of New Life Chapel. Ms Geerling has a strong focus on community, ensuring every child knows they are valued and loved unconditionally. She is currently preparing to launch her latest book, continuing her commitment to storytelling to connect and inspire the next generation.

CAITLIN WEPPNER

Caitlin Weppner embodies a 'can-do' attitude . She's been a leader with the 3rd Wodonga Scout Group since 2012, she earned the prestigious Australian Scout Award in 2022 and represented the nation at the World Scout Jamboree in South Korea. Her commitment to service is extensive: she has completed Wildfire Firefighter training with the CFA (including running with the West Wodonga Junior CFA team) and participated in the Girls on Fire Program, which focuses on emergency management skills. Recognised for her dedication and teamwork, Ms Weppner received the Australian Defence Force Year 10 Long Tan Youth Leadership Award in 2023. She also maintains her connection to the arts as a regular in the Albury Gang Show and demonstrates civic pride by carrying the flag for the 4th Light Horse Brigade at the Melbourne Anzac Day March.

ABIGAIL HONEYWOOD

Abigail Honeywood is a youth development coach and social connections champion at the Education First Youth Foyer. While completing a Bachelor of Psychological Science, she supports young people at risk of homelessness, equipping them with life skills, confidence, and independence. Her commitment extends across the region: she volunteers with the L2P mentor driving program to help youth gain their licence and uses her personal experience to champion the creation of inclusive, queer-friendly spaces. Through her work, she directly supports personal growth and resilience for young people across the Border community.

MIKAELA GOULD

Mikaela Gould is a focused, energetic, and motivated real estate professional with Stean Nicholls, known for her communication skills and welcoming disposition. A lifetime Albury resident, Ms Gould has built her career on integrity and approachability. Her diverse background, which spans retail management, sales, and property administration, allows her to deliver strong buyer and seller-focused service. She works alongside the directors of Stean Nicholls, bringing exceptional attention to detail to every campaign, all while maintaining an active lifestyle through pursuits like horse riding, water skiing, and snow skiing.

JACOB MILDREN

Jacob Mildren is a key figure connecting regional interests to federal policy as an adviser to the chief opposition whip, Aaron Violi MP. His work focuses on major policy challenges, such as AI and the digital economy. Civic engagement runs in the family. His father, Ron Mildren, is the former mayor of Wodonga. Mr Mildren himself was recognised as Wodonga's Young Citizen of the Year 2016 and has demonstrated a decade of commitment, including his involvement with Carols by Candlelight Wodonga.

TOBY COYLE

Toby Coyle is continuing a long family legacy of service, securing his first job with Forest Fire Management at just 18 and nearly finished with school at Victory Lutheran College. Following a passion he had held since childhood, Mr Coyle became a junior member of the brigade at the age of 11 and was operational by 16. While serving the community is his core drive, he attributes this quality to doing his part; he views this new role as a stepping stone toward his ultimate goal of becoming a police officer. For him, this commitment is more than just volunteering; it is about actively helping others and proudly maintaining a tradition of service for the next generation.

ASH WURTZ

Ash Wurtz is driven by a passion for helping others that extends far across borders, aiming to break the cycle of poverty for children in Thailand. Along with others from the region and Mercy International, he regularly travels to locations like Khon Kaen to assist children in orphanages and schools. Ash is resolutely hands-on, doing everything from concreting playgrounds and painting fences to delivering essentials like cooking utensils and washing machines. Having raised thousands of dollars for these vital resources, he considers the work an enriching experience, proving that doing his part is better than doing nothing, and showing the true power of community support.

BREE ARMSTRONG

Bree Armstrong is a successful young entrepreneur and the owner of The Beauty Hub and Lorum Lashes, with salons located in both Wodonga and Rockhampton. Ms Armstrong's Wodonga business quickly outgrew its original premises, leading her to partner with electrician Taylah Gerecke to renovate and open in a prominent, derelict building on Elgin Boulevard. Her rapid expansion across state borders and her significant investment in the heart of Wodonga highlight her entrepreneurial drive and impact on the regional beauty industry.

CONNOR AND ABBEY LINDEGREEN

Connor and Abbey Lindegreen are carrying on a cherished local legacy as the owners of Bonettis Pizza and Pasta. After working for founder Mark Bonetti since they were just 14, the siblings were personally offered the chance to buy the business when Mark decided to retire. Connor (21) and Abbey (19) both left their full-time careers to return to the takeaway and delivery store. Now 25 and 22, they manage up to 15 staff, having mastered everything from hiring and training to running a seven-day operation.

urn:contentItem:6GGF-SGW3-RRR6-614P-00000-00Two Killed In European Wildfires As Heatwave Intensifies2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisTwo Killed In European Wildfires As Heatwave Intensifies

Daniel Silva with European bureaus

August 12th, 2025 ( International Business Times Australia - Delivered by Newstex )

Two men died and thousands were forced from their homes on Tuesday as wildfires fuelled by a heatwave scorched southern Europe.

Heat alerts were issued in Italy, France, Spain, Portugal and the Balkans, with temperatures expected to soar above 40C.

The heatwave is another sign of climate change, which is fuelling longer, more intense and increasingly frequent bouts of extreme heat.

"Thanks to climate change, we now live in a significantly warmer world," Akshay Deoras, a research scientist at the meteorology department in Britain's University of Reading told AFP, adding that "many still underestimate the danger".

An employee of a Spanish equestrian centre who suffered serious burns died in hospital as winds of up to 70 kilometres (43 miles) per hour whipped flames through Tres Cantos, a wealthy suburb north of Madrid, officials said.

In Montenegro, a soldier died and another was seriously injured when their water tanker overturned while fighting wildfires in the hills north of the capital, Podgorica.

A child died of heatstroke in Italy on Monday.

The equestrian centre employee was the first fatality from dozens of wildfires that have hit Spain since a heatwave began last week.

Spanish media said he had become trapped by the flames as he tried to save horses.

Hundreds of residents of Tres Cantos fled their homes due to the risk from the fast-moving blaze, which was contained on Tuesday morning.

The fire damaged several homes and "above all" agricultural facilities, Carlos Novillo, Madrid's regional environment chief, told reporters.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said on X that rescue services "are working tirelessly to extinguish the fires" and warned: "We are at extreme risk of forest fires. Please be very cautious."

Elsewhere, about 2,000 people were evacuated from hotels and homes near the popular beaches of Tarifa in the southern region of Andalusia.

The wildfire broke out near where a similar blaze forced evacuations earlier this month.

"We managed to save the residential area at the very last second," said Antonio Sanz, the Andalusia region's interior minister.

In the northwestern region of Castile and Leon, dozens of blazes were reported, including one threatening Las Medulas, a UNESCO World Heritage site known for its ancient Roman gold mines.

The head of the regional government of Castile and Leon, Alfonso Fernandez Manueco, vowed "to act quickly and generously" once the fire is over to restore the site "to its full glory as soon as possible".

In neighbouring Portugal, firefighters battled three large wildfires, with the most serious near Trancoso in the centre of the country. More than 700 firefighters were deployed there.

Church bells rang out on Tuesday morning in Mendo Gordo, a hamlet near Trancoso, to sound the alarm as a thick column of smoke rose in the distance, images broadcast on Portuguese television showed.

Smoke and greenhouse gas emissions related to forest fires since the beginning of summer in the Northern Hemisphere are among the highest ever recorded, according to the EU climate monitor Copernicus.

Temperature records were broken at four weather stations in southern France on Monday and three-quarters of the country was under heat alerts on Tuesday, with temperatures forecast to top 40C in the Rhone Valley. The Rhone department banned outdoor public events.

Temperatures started rising on Friday in France's second heatwave in just a few weeks and could remain high into next week, according to the national weather office Meteo-France.

That would make it a 12- to 14-day stretch of extreme heat.

"It's already too hot," said Alain Bichot, 34, as he sat at a cafe terrace early on Tuesday morning in Dijon in eastern France.

"I would rather just go to the office. At least there is air conditioning there."

Eleven Italian cities, including Rome, Milan and Florence, were placed on red alert on Tuesday due to the heat.

In Montenegro, fire crews aided by military personnel were fighting a blaze around Podgorica for a second day when the water truck flipped, killing the soldier, the defence ministry said in a statement.

Authorities warned residents to stay indoors due to smoke from a forest fire raging in the hills above Podgorica.

Hundreds of soldiers and firefighters were also battling wildfires in Albania.

More than half (52 percent) of Europe and the Mediterranean basin was hit by drought in July for the fourth consecutive month, according to an AFP analysis of European Drought Observatory (EDO) data.

Drought levels in the region are the highest on record for the month of July since data collection began in 2012, exceeding the 2012-2024 average by 21 percent.

A wildfire on Mount Vesuvius has been brought under control, but Italian authorities have issued heat alerts in many citiesAFP

Wildfires have also been reported across the Balkans, including around the Montenegro capital PodgoricaAFP

Firefighters in Portugal battled three large wildfires, with the most serious near Trancoso in the centre of the countryAFP

urn:contentItem:6H0R-4TS3-RS1N-R2HF-00000-00Weekly Summary: Weyerhaeuser (WY: $23.59) falls for a second consecutive week, a two-week fall of 6%; -34c [1.4%] Vol Index 1.3 [1 is avg]2025-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:39ZLexisNexisWeekly Summary: Weyerhaeuser (WY: $23.59) falls for a second consecutive week, a two-week fall of 6%; -34c [1.4%] Vol Index 1.3 [1 is avg]

NYSE END-OF-WEEK STOCK REPORT

www.buysellsignals.com

Weyerhaeuser (NYSE:WY $23.59), the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market cap, has fallen 34.0c (or 1.4%) to close at $23.59. The stock fell for a second consecutive week on Friday bringing its two-week fall to $1.44 or 5.8%. Compared with the S&P 500 Index which fell 51.8 points (or 0.8%) in the two weeks, this represented a relative price change of -5.0%.

1.3 January 31 2022: Weyerhaeuser reports fourth quarter, record full year results

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today reported fourth quarter net earnings of $416 million, or 55 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $292 million, or 39 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.1 billion for the same period last year and net earnings of $482 million for the third quarter of 2021. Excluding a total after-tax benefit of $49 million for special items, the company reported fourth quarter net earnings of $367 million, or 49 cents per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $361 million for the same period last year and $450 million for the third quarter of 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2021 was $674 million compared with $657 million for the same period last year and $746 million for the third quarter of 2021.

For the full year 2021, Weyerhaeuser reported record net earnings of $2.6 billion, or $3.47 per diluted share, on net sales of $10.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $797 million on net sales of $7.5 billion for the full year 2020. Full year 2021 includes a total after-tax benefit of $81 million for special items. Excluding these items, the company reported net earnings of $2.5 billion, or $3.37 per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $962 million for the full year 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for full year 2021 was a record $4.1 billion compared with $2.2 billion for full year 2020.

This morning, the company declared a $1.45 per share supplemental dividend. On a combined basis, including dividends and share repurchase, the company is returning more than $2 billion of cash, or 79 percent of 2021 Adjusted FAD, to shareholders based on our 2021 results.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 4 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

SECTION 9 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

9.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

urn:contentItem:6GG8-91F3-RRMS-0443-00000-00Child Dies In Italy As European Heatwave Sets Records And Sparks Wildfires2025-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisChild Dies In Italy As European Heatwave Sets Records And Sparks Wildfires

AFP news

August 11th, 2025 ( International Business Times Australia - Delivered by Newstex )

A young boy died of heatstroke in Italy while wildfires threatened a UNESCO site in Spain and French cites saw record temperatures, as a heatwave baked Europe on Monday.

The four-year-old Romanian boy died days after being found unconscious in the family's car in Sardinia.

The boy was airlifted to a Rome hospital but died of irreversible brain damage, the hospital told AFP on Monday.

The news came as Italy's health ministry issued a red alert warning for seven major cities, including Bologna and Florence.

Some 11 Italian cities are on red alert for Tuesday, and 16 cities on Wednesday, while around 190 firefighters and the army continue to tackle a wildfire on Mount Vesuvius that caused the closure of the national park to tourists.

Wildfires damaged a UNESCO World Heritage-listed site in northwestern Spain and forced evacuations in three Balkan countries as high temperatures fanned by strong winds left parts of Europe in flames.

Spanish firefighters struggled to contain a wildfire that damaged a Roman-era mining site in Las Medulas and prompted hundreds of residents to evacuate.

High temperatures and winds of up to 40 kilometres per hour (25 mph) created "many difficulties", said Juan Carlos Suarez-Quinones, the Castile and Leon regional environment minister.

"We will not allow people to return until safety in their communities is absolutely guaranteed," he told reporters, estimating that about 700 people had been displaced.

Four people, including two firefighters, suffered minor injuries, he added.

The blaze broke out on Sunday near Las Medulas, an area famed for its striking red landscape.

Spain has been in the grip of a heatwave for the past week, with temperatures nearing 40C in many areas and fuelling wildfires.

Castile and Leon alone has seen 13 fires in the past three days, according to Suarez-Quinones, who said that some were believed to have been deliberately started.

In neighbouring Portugal, firefighters were battling three large wildfires in the centre and north of the country.

People were evacuated from dozens of homes in the Balkans as firefighters battled blazes in Albania, Montenegro and Croatia, where red alerts were announced.

In Albania, hundreds of firefighters and soldiers had subdued most of the nearly 40 fires that flared up in the last 24 hours, according to the defence ministry, but more than a dozen were still active.

Fires continued to burn in the southern coastal area of Finiq, around 160 kilometres south of the capital, where about 10 people were evacuated and several homes were razed on Sunday night, according to local media.

Since the start of July, nearly 34,000 hectares (84,000 acres) have been scorched nationwide, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

Police allege that many of the blazes were deliberately lit, with more than 20 people arrested in recent weeks.

Just outside the capital of neighbouring Montenegro, where temperatures soared to 40C, fire crews managed to save dozens of homes when a blaze broke out in inaccessible terrain on Monday, the commander of the Protection and Rescue Service, Nikola Bojanovic, told media.

In Croatia, around 150 firefighters also spent the night defending homes from a blaze near the port city of Split.

In the northwestern Turkish province of Canakkale, more than 2,000 people were evacuated and 77 people received hospital treatment for smoke inhalation after several fires broke out around the tourist village of Guzelyali, authorities said.

Several homes and cars caught ablaze, according to images shown on Turkish media, while more than 760 firefighters, 10 aeroplanes, nine helicopters and more than 200 vehicles were deployed to battle the flames.

Turkey had just experienced its hottest July since records began 55 years ago.

Temperature records were broken in at least four weather stations in southern France, as the government called for vigilance.

The southwestern city of Bordeaux hit a record 41.6C while all-time records were also broken at meteorological stations in Bergerac, Cognac and Saint Girons, according to the national weather service, Meteo France.

The heatwave, the country's second this summer, began on Friday and was forecast to last possibly until August 19 or 20.

On Monday, 12 French departments were placed on red alert, the country's highest heat warning, with four more expected on Tuesday.

Spanish firefighters struggled to contain a wildfire that damaged the Las Medulas Roman-era mining site and forced hundreds of residents to evacuateAFP

The blaze broke out on Sunday near the Las Medulas Roman gold-mining area famed for its striking red landscapeAFP

Around 190 firefighters and the army tackled a wildfire on Mount Vesuvius that forced the closure of the national park to touristsAFP

urn:contentItem:6GB4-8N93-RS24-G071-00000-00Services shortchanged2025-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Services shortchangedPeter Hunt

Only 20c in every dollar Victorians pay in emergency services tax will go to the CFA this financial year, with VicSES picking up less than 5c in 100c.

Premier Jacinta Allan and Treasurer Jaclyn Symes have repeatedly stated their emergency services tax on all household and businesses 2025-26 rate notices would deliver "a massive funding boost for new trucks, equipment and technology" for both volunteer services.

But on the ground, volunteers say they are being short changed, gaining less under the $1.54bn Emergency Services Volunteer Fund scheme than they did under the $1bn Fire Services Property levy it replaced.

Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria chief executive Adam Barnett said "despite documenting a record tax hike under its new Emergency Services Tax, less of that money is making its way to CFA than ever before".

Former Treasurer Tim Pallas told parliament's Public Accounts and Estimates Committee last year the CFA's forecast budget for 2024-25 was $337.6m.

Yet at the end of May this year Ms Symes signed a government gazette that stated $312m of the tax would be used to cover 95 per cent of the CFA's 2025-26 budget, bringing the total allocation to $328m - equal to a $9m cut.

Ms Symes, the Premier and Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward have denied the cutback, but refused to reveal the CFA budget allocation when repeatedly questioned by parliament's Public Accounts and Estimates Committee.

Ms Ward told PAEC in June "that would have been a conversation between Treasury and the CFA".

Ms Allan told PAEC there was funding "from other parts of government that goes into our emergency services", such as $250m announced in last December's budget update. But the update shows the $250m is spread out over four years, with just $50m a year allocated to "supporting our emergency services and volunteers", with no detail on whether the funds will be spent on the CFA and VicSES or other emergency services.

Mr Barnett said the government had rolled out a series of confusing figures, such as the promise to spend $70m on "rolling fleet" replacement. "That's $10m a year for CFA ($40m), and $7.5m for SES over four years ($30m)." On other occasions the Treasurer and Minister have inflated the "rolling fleet" investment to $110m by adding another a $40m allocated to FRV trucks, at a rate of $10m/yr over four financial years.

"Talk about how many ways can you spin a single depressingly tiny figure," Mr Barnett said.

Meanwhile analysis of the tax take, based on Ms Symes' May 30 gazette, shows half the $1.54bn tax will go to Fire Rescue Victoria, while seven other government agencies share in a $391m slice of the pie.

Under the FSPL, only the CFA and FRV could be funded using ratepayers' levy contributions.

But the new ESVF Act has allowed the government to use the 2025-26 tax take to fund 43.3 per cent of its agencies budgets, allocating: $174m to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

$107m to Triple Zero Victoria.

$78m for the Emergency Management Operational Communication Program. $12.2m to Emergency Recovery Victoria.

$11m to Emergency Management Victoria.

$8.8m for the Emergency Alert Program.

$174,973 to the State Control Centre.

VOLUNTEERS' SLICE 2025-26 allocation of $1.538 billion in Emergency Services Tax: Just 20 cents in the dollar goes to CFA volunteers 50% Fire Rescue Victoria 25% Government services 20% Country Fire Authority 5% Victorian State Emergency Service Source: VictorianGovernment

Daniel Martinez with Chantal Valery in Toulouse

August 6th, 2025 ( International Business Times Australia - Delivered by Newstex )

French firefighters on Wednesday battled to halt the spread of a wildfire in the south of the country that has left one person dead as emergency workers in Spain fought a fire that has forced the evacuation of more than 1,500 people from a resort.

With Europe facing fresh August heatwaves as concerns grow over the impact of global warming, many areas are on alert for the risk of wildfires.

Winds were hampering efforts to put out a wildfire raging Wednesday near the Spanish Mediterranean tourist town of Tarifa that prompted evacuations, the regional government said.

Meanwhile the French blaze, which started on Tuesday, has destroyed or damaged 25 homes in the southern Aude department, where some 2,000 firefighters are struggling to control the largest wildfire in France this summer.

It has killed one person and injured 13 others, two of them seriously.

"The fire is still very active and the situation remains unfavourable," said Lucie Roesch, secretary general of the Aude prefecture, citing drought conditions, rising temperatures and strong winds.

An elderly woman died in her home, one person is missing and two people were injured, one of whom is now in critical condition with severe burns, according to the Aude prefecture.

The 13 injured included nine firefighters.

The wildfire is a "catastrophe on an unprecedented scale" triggered by global warming, said French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou while on a visit to the affected Aude region.

"What is happening today is linked to global warming and linked to drought," Bayrou added.

The blaze has burned some 16,000 hectares (39,500 acres) of land in less than 24 hours.

Planes were dropping water on the flames, but Roesch warned "this fire will keep us busy for several days. It's a long-term operation".

Camping grounds and at least one village were partially evacuated, and several roads were closed.

"I left everything behind me," said David Cerdan, a 51-year-old who fled Saint-Laurent-de-la-Cabrerisse, where a woman in her 60s died after she refused to leave her home.

"I'm putting it into perspective. I only have material damage," said Cerdan, who lived near the victim.

The wildfire is the biggest in France so far in a summer which has already seen some 9,000 fires, mainly along the Mediterranean coast, according to the emergency management service.

An investigation has been opened into the cause of the fire, said local officials.

"All of the nation's resources are mobilised," President Emmanuel Macron said on X, calling on people to exercise "the utmost caution".

The Aude department in particular has seen an increase in areas burnt in recent years, aggravated by low rainfall and the uprooting of vineyards, which used to help slow down the advance of fires.

Strong, changing winds made the firefighters' job particularly difficult, officials said.

People as far as 30 kilometres (18 miles) away from the fire have felt its impact.

"The air is suffocating...the smell of burning has seeped into homes," said Serge de Souza, a local in the seaside town of Port-la-Nouvelle.

The frequency of wildfires is taking a toll on local residents, said Aude Damesin, who lives in the town of Fabrezan.

"It's terrible for the wildlife, the flora, and for the people who are losing everything," she said.

The European Union's crisis management commissioner, Hadja Lahbib, said on X that "the EU stands ready to mobilise international support, if needed".

Although fire crews had secured areas near hotels and other tourist accommodation, the fire in Spain's Tarifa was still not under control, said officials.

"What concerns us most right now is the wind -- whether it shifts between the west and east," said Antonio Sanz, interior minister for Andalusia's regional government.

Spanish public broadcaster TVE reported that the fire had started in a camper van at a beachside campsite, before being quickly spread by strong winds.

About 1,550 people and 5,500 vehicles were evacuated from campsites, hotels, and homes, said Sanz.

Emergency crews worked through the night to prevent the fire from reaching coastal resorts, but residents and tourists have not been allowed to return, he added.

Climate experts say that global warming is driving longer, more intense and more frequent heatwaves around the world, making for more favourable forest fire conditions.

France has recorded around 9,000 fires halfway through the summer seasonAFP

Weather conditions are expected to remain unfavorable in coming daysAFP

Authorities mobilised more than 1,800 firefighters on Wednesday morningAFP

Some 24,000 hectares have burned in France since the start of the yearAFP

The fire has killed a woman in her 60sAFP

A French civil defence helicopter ready to drop water on the fireAFP

urn:contentItem:6G8Y-0X13-RTDC-Y11N-00000-00'Less than ever before': CFA to get just 20c in tax dollar2025-07-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexis'Less than ever before': CFA to get just 20c in tax dollar

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt

Only 20c in every dollar Victorians pay in emergency services tax will go to the CFA this financial year, with VicSES's picking up less than 5c in 100c.

Premier Jacinta Allan and Treasurer Jaclyn Symes have repeatedly stated their emergency services tax on all household and businesses 2025-26 rate notices would deliver "a massive funding boost for new trucks, equipment and technology" for both volunteer services.

But on the ground, volunteers say they are being short changed, gaining less under the $1.54 billion Emergency Services Volunteer Fund taxation scheme than they did under $1 billion Fire Services Property levy it replaced.

Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria chief executive Adam Barnett said "despite documenting a record tax hike under its new Emergency Services Tax, less of that money is making its way to CFA than ever before".

Former Treasurer Tim Pallas told Parliament's Public Accounts and Estimates Committee last year the CFA's forecast budget for 2024-25 was $337.6m.

Yet at the end of May this year Ms Symes signed a government gazette that stated $312m of the tax would be used to cover 95 per cent of the CFA's 2025-26 budget, bringing the total allocation to $328m - equal to a $9m cut.

Ms Symes, the Premier and Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward have denied the cutback, but have refused to reveal the CFA budget allocation when repeatedly questioned by Parliament's Public Accounts and Estimates Committee.

Ms Ward told PAEC in June "that would have been a conversation between Treasury and the CFA".

Ms Allan told PAEC there was funding "from other parts of government that goes into our emergency services", such as $250m announced in last December's budget update.

But the update shows the $250m is spread out over four years, with just $50m a year allocated to "supporting our emergency services and volunteers", with no detail on whether the funds will be spent on the CFA and VicSES or other emergency services.

Mr Barnett said the government had rolled out a series of confusing figures, such as

the promise to spend $70m on "rolling fleet" replacement.

"That's $10m a year for CFA ($40m), and $7.5m for SES over four years ($30m).

On other occasions the Treasurer and Minister have inflated the "rolling fleet" investment to $110m by adding another a $40m allocated to FRV trucks, at a rate of $10m/yr over four financial years.

"Talk about how many ways can you spin a single depressingly tiny figure," Mr Barnett said.

Meanwhile analysis of the tax take, based on Ms Symes' May 30 gazette, shows half the $1.54 billion tax will go to Fire Rescue Victoria, while seven other government agencies share in a $391m slice of the pie.

Under the FSPL, only the CFA and FRV could be funded using ratepayers' levy contributions.

But the new ESVF Act has allowed the government to use the 2025-26 tax take to fund 43.3 per cent of its agencies budgets, allocating:

$174m to Forest Fire Management Victoria.

$107m to Triple Zero Victoria.

$78m for the Emergency Management Operational Communication Program.

$12.2m to Emergency Recovery Victoria.

$11m to Emergency Management Victoria.

$8.8m for the Emergency Alert Program.

$174,973 to the State Control Centre.

Mahmut Bozarslan with Anne Chaon

July 28th, 2025 ( International Business Times Australia - Delivered by Newstex )

Firefighters battled blazes across Turkey on Monday as the country sweltered in a summer heatwave across much of the Mediterranean, with wildfires leading to at least 14 deaths in the country in the past week.

Around 20 villages have been evacuated, officials said, and more than 3,500 people forced to leave their homes.

"We are burning up, we don't even know where to go anymore," Asmin Gezginci, 24, said while returning from a park to her home in the Kurdish-majority southeastern city of Diyarbakir.

Temperatures had already soared to a record high of 50.5 degrees Celsius (123 Fahrenheit) on Friday in Silopi, two hours from Gezginci's home.

According to weather forecasts, the heatwave will continue this week with temperatures of 40C to 45C in the central Anatolia region and 45C to 50C forecast in the southeast on Tuesday.

On Monday, local authorities in Diyarbakir warned residents about temperatures "four to six degrees above seasonal norms until August 2".

In the city, the thermometer was already showing 45.4C at midday, an AFP journalist saw.

The heatwave has exacerbated forest fires on the dry ground that have spread rapidly in windy conditions.

Firefighters tackled blazes around Bursa in the northwest on Monday, the country's fourth-largest city and a major industrial centre, for the third consecutive day.

Their efforts were hampered by strong winds fanning the flames, according to Agriculture and Forestry Minister Ibrahim Yumakli.

Some residents used tractors to transport water tanks, while television images showed others rushing toward the blazes with bottles of water in their hands.

But the intensity of a fire in Karabuk in the north has diminished, and a fire in Kahramanmaras in the south is now "under control", Yumakli said.

"Given the size and intensity of the fires, the state's ability to respond quickly to such disasters is sometimes limited," he acknowledged.

"If there is wind, there are no planes, and it takes hours, even days, for you to take control," he said.

In recent days, 19 villages had to be evacuated in the Safranbolu region in the north, and more than 3,500 people around Bursa.

In a televised speech after a weekly cabinet meeting, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said 96 percent of the fires were caused by human activity such as cigarette butts and picnic fires.

There were also a few cases of sabotage, he said.

"Let us not forget that this is a war, a defence of our green homeland, against this insidious enemy," Erdogan said.

"We are doing what is necessary, and we will continue to do so."

Last week, a wildfire killed at least 10 forest workers and rescuers fighting a blaze near Eskisehir in western Turkey.

A firefighter battling the flames died of a heart attack on Saturday.

Three more people died Sunday in an accident involving a water tanker truck that was used to battle a blaze, Bursa authorities said.

According to Erdogan, more than 3,000 fires have broken out since the beginning of summer, and authorities warn the situation will remain critical until October.

A UN report on desertification worldwide estimates that 88 percent of Turkey's territory is at risk: rainfall is expected to decrease 30 percent by the end of the century, while temperatures are expected to rise by 5C to 6C compared to the averages recorded between 1961 and 1990.

Across the Aegean Sea in Greece, where blazes have ravaged homes and sparked evacuations across the country this summer, firefighters worked Monday to contain outbreaks after bringing dozens under control over the weekend.

Even as the heat wave gripping the country began to ease, a new forest fire broke out near the university campus east of Athens, in the municipality of Zografou.

According to firefighters, 65 firefighters, 20 vehicles, seven helicopters and six planes were mobilised to contain the flames.

Greece has endured heatwave conditions for a week, with temperatures passing 40C in many areas.

And on the Iberian Peninsula, four Spanish planes joined more than 250 Portuguese firefighters battling a blaze Monday in an isolated mountain region near their border, authorities said.

The blaze in north Portugal's Viana do Castelo district was spreading in two directions and difficult to tackle because of the strong winds, civil protection chief Marco Domingues said.

One firefighter has been injured.

Authorities have put much of northern and southern Portugal on the highest alert for wildfires because of high temperatures and strong winds.

1.3 January 31 2022: Weyerhaeuser reports fourth quarter, record full year results

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today reported fourth quarter net earnings of $416 million, or 55 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $292 million, or 39 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.1 billion for the same period last year and net earnings of $482 million for the third quarter of 2021. Excluding a total after-tax benefit of $49 million for special items, the company reported fourth quarter net earnings of $367 million, or 49 cents per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $361 million for the same period last year and $450 million for the third quarter of 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2021 was $674 million compared with $657 million for the same period last year and $746 million for the third quarter of 2021.

For the full year 2021, Weyerhaeuser reported record net earnings of $2.6 billion, or $3.47 per diluted share, on net sales of $10.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $797 million on net sales of $7.5 billion for the full year 2020. Full year 2021 includes a total after-tax benefit of $81 million for special items. Excluding these items, the company reported net earnings of $2.5 billion, or $3.37 per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $962 million for the full year 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for full year 2021 was a record $4.1 billion compared with $2.2 billion for full year 2020.

This morning, the company declared a $1.45 per share supplemental dividend. On a combined basis, including dividends and share repurchase, the company is returning more than $2 billion of cash, or 79 percent of 2021 Adjusted FAD, to shareholders based on our 2021 results.

"Our 2021 financial performance was the strongest on record and each of our businesses delivered exceptional results despite persistent operational and market challenges," said Devin W.

October 07: Weyerhaeuser Company Supports Row River with Land Donation for Fire Substation

COTTAGE GROVE, Ore. - Weyerhaeuser Company Tuesday announced it has donated 38 acres of land in Disston, Ore. to Row River Fire Response (RRFR). The donated land, which connects the Row River and Lower Brice Creek areas, will serve as the site for a new RRFR emergency substation facility for the Row River Rural Fire Protection, aimed at improving wildfire response times. This announcement comes on the 7th of October, 2025, reflecting Weyerhaeuser's ongoing commitment to community and environmental responsibility.

RRFR is an Oregon 501(c)(3) nonprofit that provides support for fire and emergency services in the Row River Valley, a rural area outside Cottage Grove that experiences high wildfire risk each summer. Historically, this region has not had rapid access to city fire department services. Weyerhaeuser noted in a media release that rural fire protection districts often operate with limited resources and are frequently the first responders to wildfires in remote or hard-to-reach areas across Oregon.

Lyndcy Patrick, land use manager at Weyerhaeuser, stated, "Thriving, resilient communities are vital to the well-being of our employees, our neighbors, and the places where we live and work in Oregon. By supporting organizations like RRFR, Weyerhaeuser can make a real difference in wildfire response and help ensure these first responders can keep our communities and forests healthy." This donation follows a $25,000 grant Weyerhaeuser awarded to RRFR in 2023 through its Giving Fund to support infrastructure costs for the new fire facility.

The new Disston Substation will be a satellite fire station equipped with a fire truck and water tender. This facility is expected to significantly enhance emergency response times in Dorena, Culp Creek, and surrounding areas. Kathleen Istudor, Executive Director at RRFR, expressed gratitude, stating, "We can't thank Weyerhaeuser enough for this generous donation and their support for the strength and resilience of rural communities.

October 07: Weyerhaeuser's $1 Million Commitment to Buckhannon Signals Long-Term Strategy

BUCKHANNON, W.Va. (WV News) - Weyerhaeuser Company has announced a commitment to invest $1 million in Buckhannon through the company's THRIVE program. This investment will be made over the next several years, with input from local elected officials, business leaders, nonprofits, employees, and other community partners. The announcement comes as part of Weyerhaeuser's ongoing efforts to enhance rural communities, marking Buckhannon as the third selected community since the program's launch in 2023.

Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer of Weyerhaeuser, emphasized the significance of rural operating communities for the company's success. "Rural operating communities like Buckhannon are so important to the success of our business and to the greater health of the forest products industry," Stockfish stated. "We want to make sure these communities remain great places to live, work, and do business for years to come. We are looking forward to growing the positive impact of our THRIVE program as we expand it in Buckhannon and the surrounding area."

Weyerhaeuser has maintained an engineered wood products plant in Buckhannon for over 25 years, consistently ranking among its top-performing sites for safety and manufacturing reliability. In addition, the company operates an oriented strand board mill in nearby Sutton and sustainably manages over 250,000 acres of timberlands across West Virginia. The investment in Buckhannon is seen as a significant step towards fostering a collaborative relationship between the company and the local community.

Robbie Skinner, mayor of Buckhannon, expressed enthusiasm about the investment, noting, "We are excited and grateful to be selected as Weyerhaeuser's next THRIVE community. This investment is a clear signal of Weyerhaeuser's commitment to Buckhannon, and we look forward to partnering with company leaders and the people of this great community to build a stronger and better future together." The THRIVE program aims to address local challenges through long-term collaboration, investment, and advocacy.

Nancy Thompson, senior director of Advocacy and Philanthropy at Weyerhaeuser, highlighted that each THRIVE community has unique needs and priorities.

September 02: Weyerhaeuser Concludes Sale of Princeton Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Weyerhaeuser Company has completed the sale of its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group. This transaction, initially announced in May, includes the transfer of Weyerhaeuser's associated timber licenses in British Columbia, which are expected to be finalized in the coming months, subject to regulatory review and customary closing conditions.

As part of the sale, Weyerhaeuser received approximately $60 million USD upfront, with additional proceeds tied to the transfer of the timber licenses. The company has recognized a gain from the sale but anticipates a tax liability of about $11 million USD as a result of the transaction. This sale reflects Weyerhaeuser's ongoing strategy to optimize its operations and focus on its core business areas.

Established in 1900, Weyerhaeuser is among the largest private owners of timberlands worldwide, managing approximately 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and additional public timberlands in Canada. The company is recognized for its commitment to sustainability, operating all its timberlands in compliance with internationally recognized forestry standards. In 2024, Weyerhaeuser reported net sales of $7.1 billion and employed around 9,400 people globally.

The Gorman Group, a family-owned business founded in 1951, operates multiple divisions in Southern British Columbia and northern Washington state, employing about 900 individuals. The company is well-regarded for its high-value lumber products, particularly in the home finishing and renovation markets. The acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's mill aligns with Gorman Group's long-term strategy of enhancing its operational capabilities and market presence.

Weyerhaeuser's decision to divest its Princeton mill is part of a broader trend in the timber industry, where companies are reassessing their portfolios to focus on areas with higher growth potential.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. SECTION 4 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.
