SECTION 9 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

9.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

urn:contentItem:6FYJ-1JW3-RRS8-94KG-00000-00'Team effort' rescues Ted the dog from eight-metre mine shaft2025-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisNEWS4'Team effort' rescues Ted the dog from eight-metre mine shaftJonathon Magrath

A local CFA crew and specialist rescue team helped rescue the dog.

A dog has been rescued after falling down an eight-metre-deep mine shaft near Daylesford .

Labrador Ted was found down the mine on Pronk Track in Trentham about 11.45am on Monday.

Labradoodle Penny was found on the track, after both dogs were reported missing on social media.

Trentham Fire Brigade was called to the incident with CFA's Bendigo-based Oscar 1 mine rescue team called to travel down the shaft.

Captain David Wheeldon, of the Trentham brigade, said a neighbour heard barking and called triple-0.

"When we arrived, as you would expect, Penny was quite agitated, but luckily one of our firefighters knew the owners because they lived next door to them," Captain Wheeldon said.

"We were able to get a hold of them to come down before Bendigo's Oscar 1 crew started the rescue process.

"Throughout the morning, we were providing Ted with plenty of food and water."

Oscar 1 crew members descended the shaft and extricated Ted, handing him back to his owners before 3pm "happy, healthy and well".

Trentham Fire Brigade members worked with Forest Fire Management Victoria to track the dogs' location with pink ribbons and red-taped open mine shafts nearby to prevent future incidents, a CFA spokesperson said.

Ted with a rescuer. Picture supplied

Ted with a rescuer. Picture supplied

urn:contentItem:6FDV-1R83-RS0F-N0P9-00000-00Burning desire to reduce bushfire impact will spread across 46,300 hectares2025-03-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisBurning desire to reduce bushfire impact will spread across 46,300 hectares

Bonegilla fires among more than 100 North East planned burns.

Two planned burns in Bonegilla this week are among more than 100 to take place across 46,300 hectares in North East Victoria.

Upper Murray Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters completed the Bonegilla grasslands burns, which totalled four hectares, on Tuesday, March 25.

Priority burns are planned in North East state forests, parks and reserves including around Bright, Beechworth, Yackandandah, Mitta, Koetong and Tallangatta Valley.

FFMVic deputy chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said firefighters used planned burning to lessen the size, intensity, and impact of bushfires.

"Reducing fuels such as grass, leaves, bark, shrubs and small fallen branches means fires are less intense, slower to spread and safer for firefighters to control," Mr Kennedy said.

"Autumn is generally the best time of the year to undertake planned burns as the weather is more stable and fire behaviour is manageable and predictable."

In locations where planned burning isn't suitable, firefighters mulch, mow, slash and spray, build fuel breaks and upgrade and maintain the public land road network.

"We work with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess weather conditions, such as humidity, temperature and wind speed and will only carry out burns when the conditions are suitable, and it is safe to do so," Mr Kennedy said.

People can register for the latest updates about planned burning locations and times at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au/ .

Forest Fire Management Victoria intends to conduct more than 100 planned burns in the North East over autumn. Pictures supplied

Forest Fire Management Victoria intends to conduct more than 100 planned burns in the North East over autumn. Pictures supplied

urn:contentItem:6D6N-JPX1-JBJ7-N3W5-00000-00Forest fire redundancies 'risk emergency responses'2024-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisForest fire redundancies 'risk emergency responses'

Victoria's environment department is looking to make 208 people redundant in its bushfire and forest services group, including 118 in forest fire operations.

Victorian towns devastated in the deadly Black Saturday blazes are at risk of being exposed again in an emergency under a proposed restructure of the forest fire workforce that will close depots, the Australian Workers Union has warned.

The Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action (DEECA) is planning to make 208 people redundant in its bushfire and forest services group, including 118 in forest fire operations - a move the department acknowledges could risk its contribution to emergency management in the short to medium term.

Many of those working back-of-house at the department also have a frontline role fighting fires and in other emergencies through Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic).

The AWU is now considering joining the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU) as it takes the state government to the Fair Work Commission over the cuts.

Under its plan, DEECA is also looking to close some of its 99 regional work centres to cut costs and redirect funds to higher risk areas - but the AWU has warned that would leave gaps in coverage during emergencies.

"The proposed closure of the Lysterfield and Plenty Gorge work centres will also leave geographical gaps in coverage for emergency response," the union said in its formal response - obtained by The Age - to the department this month.

"With Melbourne Water also closing their Kinglake work centre, and DEECA slated to do the same, there will be significantly less coverage in areas that were greatly impacted by the Black Saturday fires."

The 2009 Black Saturday bushfires killed 173 people in Victoria and burned through more than 400,000 hectares.

Nathalia, in the state's north, in particular needed equipment and variable staff for emergencies and to retain response times, the union said. New satellite depots may also be necessary as they close other sites, it said.

Under DEECA's proposal, frontline field staff would be bolstered with 54 extra workers.

Link to Image

DEECA

But the AWU said some "new" positions were actually existing back-of-house jobs shifted onto the lower-paid field workforce - not the promised extra resources. Given some field staff roles were also being cut, the union has asked for a breakdown to get a better understanding of total new jobs.

Lead organiser Ross Kenna said the AWU was considering lodging a dispute with Fair Work.

The CPSU has already done so, with a hearing listed for Friday. That union, which claimed the department had failed to meaningfully consult on the changes, also said its members would be disadvantaged by their existing work shifting into lower-paid field positions.

The forest fire operations team - where 118 jobs could be lost - "delivers integrated land and fire management activities across state forests", according to department documents.

As part of FFMVic, the division also undertakes "bushfire management across all public land in Victoria, and supports other Class 1 and Class 2 emergencies", which have the potential to be or are deadly.

Consultation documents circulated to staff in August - also obtained by The Age - acknowledged that cutting this division "may reduce ability in the short to medium term to contribute to sector-wide [emergency management] arrangements".

This was especially true for cross-district taskforces, particularly non-fire emergencies and incident management team roles in which DEECA is not the control agency. "However the seasonal [emergency management] workforce framework will help mitigate this risk."

The document said the change would streamline planning and result in better integration of forest and fire management.

All up, the bushfire and forest services group will drop from 1925 staff to 1717. Other proposed cuts include 34 workers in the conservation regulator, 36 in infrastructure and resources, and 20 in policy and planning.

The department said it had not reviewed its operations since 2017 and that its role changed when the Parks Victoria fire program was transferred to DEECA, and since the ban on native timber logging.

The department, which will finalise the restructure this month, also has a role managing the bird flu outbreak and responding to floods and storms.

Parks Victoria is also separately in the early stages of a possible restructure.

A government spokeswoman said the 54 new forest firefighter roles at FFMVic would be funded through a $36.9 million investment, and that $20 million would upgrade critical forest fire emergency equipment.

"Our capacity to deliver bushfire management works or respond in an emergency has not changed - there is no decrease in the number of field staff under these proposed changes," she said.

DEECA deputy secretary Kelly Crosthwaite said it was working through feedback on the proposed operating model that would "deliver value for taxpayers and make sure we have the right people working on the right things".

"No frontline firefighting roles are being reduced - in fact we're adding more full-time operational roles - and our incident management capacity and regional presence will be maintained. Victorians can be assured we'll continue to protect communities and the things they care about from bushfire risk."

On Thursday, Emergency Services Minister Jaclyn Symes said Victoria should prepare for an early start to the fire season in the west of the state after a dry winter.

She said the rest of the state could be described as a normal fire season but that this could change if Victoria didn't get much rain by January.

Symes said a wild hail storm in Casterton in Victoria's west on Wednesday night was an example of localised weather events becoming more frequent and severe with climate change.

DEECA says no frontline firefighting roles are being reduced under its planned restructure.

urn:contentItem:6G7S-KXS3-RRVF-22CG-00000-00Tiny chef, big dining experience2025-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 17Tiny chef, big dining experienceAlix Davis

Indulge I'm not averse to dinner and a show, but I've never been to a dinner where the show actually takes place on the table. No, we're not talking dancing girls sashaying through the silverware, instead we are watching a highly animated - and somewhat hapless - chef who is just 6cm tall. If you're not sure what I'm talking about, relax, neither was I until I attended the Le Petit Chef experience at DoubleTree by Hilton Hobart's Leatherwood restaurant.

Created in Marseille, France in 2010, Le Petit Chef is a unique 3D video installation that brings your table to life, with each course following the adventures of a tiny chef. Your plate is part of the performance space and "ingredients" are flung onto the crockery by the chef as he gardens, fishes and manages to start a forest fire. Each course is then realised by a real-life chef - in our case, Nathan Chilcott who heads up the Leatherwood team.

While the menu is set by Le Petit Chef, the dishes are open to interpretation by the restaurant's chef and, as the experience is available in more than 100 locations around the world, the final dishes are many and varied.

We begin with a caprese salad - after Le Petit Chef has battled a mole in his garden. Confit tomatoes capture the flavour of summer, even in winter, and a marinated mozzarella is mild and flavourful. An olive crumb is a nod to the garden's soil and adds a lovely salty hit.

Given the nature of the experience, it's a set menu with vegetarian and children's options available. The classic and vegetarian menus are $149 per person and the junior menu (ages 6-12) is $89 per person. You're welcome to Leatherwood's wine list or can choose matched wines from cricketer Ricky Ponting's label for an additional $50 per person.

Once Le Petit Chef has successfully fended off an octopus attack (I promise, this will all make sense once you're there!) we enjoyed a Tasmanian bouillabaisse full of mussels, scallops and calamari paired with a thick slice of toasted sourdough dripping with garlic butter. The soup was beautifully flavoured with a hint of saffron - a traditional ingredient in this classic dish that (just like Le Petit Chef) originated in Marseille.

Our two mains take Le Petit Chef's directions and give them a Tasmanian and Australian twist with a kunzea-marinated chicken breast served with potatoes, beans and a richly flavoured jus. A perfectly cooked beef striploin sits alongside saltbush potato gratin and delicate baby carrots.

Everything is beautifully executed and the meal is worthy of standing on its on merits. However, by the sound of the squeals of delight coming from the children seated behind us, the addition of Le Petit Chef is making the restaurant experience both delicious and memorable.

This unique experience will be at Leatherwood until January and available to up to 16 diners per evening on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Given the nature of the technological logistics of the experience, I'd recommend a booking of even numbers.

Dessert is a snowy experience for Le Petit Chef and we enjoy it as a dreamy scoop of Valhalla ice cream with dark chocolate ganache, crunchy peanut brittle and delicate shards of meringue dusted with dehydrated berries.

Le Petit Chef is a delight for children and adults alike and if you're looking to introduce your smalls to restaurant dining, this could be a great way to do it - there wasn't an iPad or screen in sight!

LE PETIT CHEF @LEATHERWOOD DoubleTree by Hilton 179 Macquarie St, Hobart Opening hours: Thurs, Friday, Sat: 6pm On the menu: Caprese salad, bouillabaisse, kunzea-marinated chicken breast, grilled striploin, ice cream with chocolate ganache

Everything is beautifully executed and the meal is worthy of standing on its on merits. However, by the sound of the squeals of delight coming from the children seated behind us, the addition of Le Petit Chef is making the restaurant experience both delicious and memorable.

This unique experience will be at Leatherwood until January and available to up to 16 diners per evening on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Given the nature of the technological logistics of the experience, I'd recommend a booking of even numbers.

Dessert is a snowy experience for Le Petit Chef and we enjoy it as a dreamy scoop of Valhalla ice cream with dark chocolate ganache, crunchy peanut brittle and delicate shards of meringue dusted with dehydrated berries.

Le Petit Chef is a delight for children and adults alike and if you're looking to introduce your smalls to restaurant dining, this could be a great way to do it - there wasn't an iPad or screen in sight!

LE PETIT CHEF @ LEATHERWOOD

DoubleTree by Hilton

179 Macquarie St, Hobart

Opening hours: Thurs, Friday, Sat: 6pm

On the menu:

Caprese salad, bouillabaisse, kunzea-marinated chicken breast, grilled striploin, ice cream with chocolate ganache

September 02: Weyerhaeuser Concludes Sale of Princeton Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Weyerhaeuser Company has completed the sale of its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group. This transaction, initially announced in May, includes the transfer of Weyerhaeuser's associated timber licenses in British Columbia, which are expected to be finalized in the coming months, subject to regulatory review and customary closing conditions.

As part of the sale, Weyerhaeuser received approximately $60 million USD upfront, with additional proceeds tied to the transfer of the timber licenses. The company has recognized a gain from the sale but anticipates a tax liability of about $11 million USD as a result of the transaction. This sale reflects Weyerhaeuser's ongoing strategy to optimize its operations and focus on its core business areas.

Established in 1900, Weyerhaeuser is among the largest private owners of timberlands worldwide, managing approximately 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and additional public timberlands in Canada. The company is recognized for its commitment to sustainability, operating all its timberlands in compliance with internationally recognized forestry standards. In 2024, Weyerhaeuser reported net sales of $7.1 billion and employed around 9,400 people globally.

The Gorman Group, a family-owned business founded in 1951, operates multiple divisions in Southern British Columbia and northern Washington state, employing about 900 individuals. The company is well-regarded for its high-value lumber products, particularly in the home finishing and renovation markets. The acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's mill aligns with Gorman Group's long-term strategy of enhancing its operational capabilities and market presence.

Weyerhaeuser's decision to divest its Princeton mill is part of a broader trend in the timber industry, where companies are reassessing their portfolios to focus on areas with higher growth potential.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 4 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

SECTION 9 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

9.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

urn:contentItem:6GCW-SBX3-S107-G2H1-00000-00Samurai sword attacker fatally shot by police while strangling sister2025-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:39ZLexisNexisSamurai sword attacker fatally shot by police while strangling sister

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Olivia Jenkins, Mark Buttler, Anna Shreeves, Zoe De Koning

A man allegedly severed his sister's arm with a samurai sword and was strangling her as she lay unconscious before police officers shot him dead inside a house in the Yarra Ranges.

The siblings' mother called police to a house on the Warburton Hwy at Yarra Junction about 5.30pm on Wednesday after a fight broke out at the property.

Eastern Region Assistant Commissioner Russell Barrett, who attended the "dynamic" and "traumatic" scene late on Wednesday, said two officers arrived to find the 45-year-old man strangling his unconscious sister in a bedroom.

Assistant Commissioner Barrett said they tried to subdue the man by tasering him three times, but were forced to shoot him when he would not let go of his 48-year-old sister, whose arm had been severed above her elbow.

Paramedics tried to revive the man, but he died at the scene.

The woman remained in a coma with life-threatening injuries on Thursday morning.

Assistant Commissioner Barrett said the woman's arm had been partially severed before police arrived.

Investigators found a sword at the house and will determine whether it was the weapon the man used to attack his sister.

Assistant Commissioner Barrett said the siblings' mother warned them about the fight unfolding inside the house before they stepped inside.

He said he stood by the action taken by the senior Constable and leading senior Constable to shoot the man, saying the woman could have been killed if they hadn't.

The officers involved were distressed after the incident, describing their actions as "brave" and "entirely appropriate", he said.

"It's tragic - it's a graphic scene," he said.

"This is every police officer's nightmare.

"No police officer wants to take these actions.

"They've acted entirely appropriately and followed their training.

"Our hearts go out to the family."

Assistant Commissioner Barrett said the man had a history of mental health issues and was known to police because of his condition.

How many people were inside the family home when the fatal fight broke out and how many shots the officers fired will be central to the investigation, which will be overseen by homicide detectives and the force's Professional Standards Command - standard practice for police shootings.

Forensic specialists spent Thursday morning combing the property for evidence.

Assistant Commissioner Barrett said the ordeal unfolded over the course of about four minutes, describing footage from the officers' body worn cameras as extremely graphic.

The pair's mother was taken to hospital for assessment but was not injured during the fight.

It remained unclear whether the man was under the influence of drugs when police arrived.

Forest Fire Management Victoria contractor Ian Polkinghorne was staying at a neighbouring bed and breakfast when the incident took place on Wednesday afternoon.

"The only thing I really heard was a dog going off (and) losing its nut at one stage," he told the Herald Sun on Thursday morning.

"I thought it was a bit strange, a bit of a different bark than normal.

"I heard sirens, but thought it might have been a car crash, then walked outside to take the bins out and saw cop cars, ambulances and the helicopter, which flew over and rattled the shit out of the joint."

He added while he didn't hear any shots, it wasn't uncommon to hear guns being fired around Yarra Junction.

"Every now and again you hear deer hunters fire a gun and you can hear them even with the TV on ... but they use much bigger guns than the police."

Mr Polkinghorne said he had been staying at the accommodation located on Warburton Hwy for work for two years and had seen police at the property where the incident took place multiple times.

"I believe there have definitely been problems there before," he said.

"Every now and again you see the cops there and you just know something weird is going on."

The retired firefighter said the incident didn't worry him personally but his thoughts were with the victim and officers involved.

Long-time local Brian, who owns 3 Kings Bed & Breakfast, told the Herald Sun his family had lived a few doors down from the Warburton Hwy property for 25 years and had noticed some unusual behaviour from the people living there.

"I knew (the man) had issues because there had been an episode prior," he said.

"We would see him walking up and down the driveway and say g'day but he was a quiet, more solemn type of person.

"You just knew that all was not well and the fact that the police had attended the home previously, you knew that there were issues."

Brian said the news shocked the tight-knit community in Yarra Junction.

"This stuff happens all the time, every day, everywhere, no doubt, but when it happens in a small town of 1600 people you tend to be shocked and surprised by it," he said.

"We have never felt personally threatened or concerned for our own safety at any stage, just more sad than anything else."

Another 49-year-old man was also at the home during the fatal shooting, but was uninjured during the ordeal.

Anyone who witnessed the incident or with further information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or submit a confidential report online at www.crimestoppersvic.com.au.

urn:contentItem:6FX5-XFM3-RRWF-61XM-00000-00Volunteers can't find funds promised by new tax2025-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Volunteers can't find funds promised by new taxPeter Hunt

CFA and VICSES volunteers have been left in the dark on the Allan government's promise to spend $50m a year of its new $1.623bn emergency services tax on training and new equipment.

Announcing the tax last December, then emergency services minister Jaclyn Symes committed $50m a year over the next five years to "support CFA and VICSES volunteers across the state".

At the time, Ms Symes said $70m of the $250m five-year allocation would be spent on a rolling fleet replacement program for VICSES and the CFA, doubling the Volunteer Emergency Services Equipment Program to $62m, and $30m to deliver training and support programs.

But in her first budget as Treasurer, Ms Symes failed to list any of the volunteer programs, leaving the CFA and VICSES with no idea of what - if any - extra funds were available for new trucks, the VSEP or training.

CFA sources said the service had been "left in limbo", not knowing if funds would be allocated, delaying its order of new tankers for the oldest fleet in Australia.

The budget's only mention of truck replacement was $40m over four years for FRV's fleet and $10m for Forest Fire Management Victoria vehicles in 2025-26.

Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria chief executive Adam Barnett said "volunteers looking for reassurance in the â€¦ 2025-26 budget will be sorely disappointed". Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward's office dismissed volunteer concerns, saying $200m was allocated over the next four years in last December's 2024-25 budget update, plus another $53.1m in the budget.

urn:contentItem:6FWT-73C3-RVGB-M2B7-00000-00Active management the only way to reduce risk: Tony Bartlett2025-05-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisActive management the only way to reduce risk: Tony Bartlett

Dr Tony Bartlett, Latrobe Valley Express, 14 May 2025

The claims in my critique of research published by academics David Lindenmayer, Philip Zylstra and others are not demonstrably false and do not misrepresent scientific evidence. They are based on my own very considerable experience in forest management as well as careful consideration of both their research and the much wider body of Australian bushfire science.

Published peer-reviewed research referred to by these academics does not necessarily correlate with undeniable facts or logic when it comes to establishing sensible fores fire management policies. There is a very strong body of existing knowledge about forest fire management in Australia, much of which is based on decades of on-ground research trials and the analysis of outcomes from major bushfires.

A few new research papers, none of which have been published in recognised fire science journals, should not be the sole determinant of radical changes in forest fire management in Australia. To do so would put both communities and the environment at serious risk of major harm from future intense bushfires that will ravage through unmanaged forest landscapes.

Experienced forest firefighters will tell you that 'lived experience' is very important in determining how to reduce risks of bushfires and how to be more successful in putting them out when they occur. For example, a research paper might show that a prescribed burn conducted 8.5km away from houses only had a limited effect on reducing the risk to those houses being destroyed by a bushfire burning under catastrophic fire weather conditions.

However, lived experience will tell you that the same prescribed burn could be very effective in enabling a large scale backburn to be conducted safely and thereby in reducing the spread of a bushfire burning under more moderate conditions that could have otherwise impacted on houses when conditions worsen.

Lived experience also deserves to be considered in situations where it contradicts the findings of published research. For instance, in the 2003 Canberra bushfires, the relatively small lightning caused bushfires burning in a large National Park, where no logging had occurred, could not be controlled at relatively moderate levels of fire danger, because of the excessive fuel loads in those forests as a result of prescribed burning being excluded for decades. Those bushfires went on to claim four lives and destroy more than 500 houses in and around Canberra.

There are significant flaws in the logic and analysis of some of the published research that is used by these academics to lobby for radical changes in forest and fire management strategies. Many of these flaws have been raised in published critiques of the original research papers.

Nevertheless, these academics just dismiss these criticisms and continue to publish inaccurate findngs from their own research. For instance, in their response to my critique of their research, they again state that "logged forests burning under moderate fire weather conditions still burnt at greater severity than intact forests burning under extreme conditions" quoting their research (Lindenmayer et al. 2022b).

However, that quoted article was a short response to a critique of their claims made in an earlier two-page published article. In neither of these two articles did the academics publish their own empirical data to justify their often-repeated claim about the impact of logging on bushfire severity.

Strategically implementing more active management of native forests is the only feasible way to reduce the impacts of the increasing occurrence of severe bushfires. I strongly believe that it would be unreasonable for governments to make important bushfire policy decisions on the basis of a few new published research articles without a proper consideration of the alternative evidence.

About the author: Dr Tony Bartlett AFSM has worked in Australian and international forestry for close to 50 years, and has worked in various forestry roles for the Commonwealth, ACT and Victorian government.

Related stories:Burning off the key to intensity; Disturbance and fire risks: the science clearly shows logging and burning makes forests more flammable: David Lindenmayer, Philip Zylstra

urn:contentItem:6FX5-XFM3-RRWF-630M-00000-00The WEEKLY TIMES2025-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 18The WEEKLY TIMES

Allan's all talk, no action Regional Victorians have every right to question an Allan Labor Government that talks big, but delivers little.

Evidence of just how little can be found buried away in the back pages of last week's budget performance measures.

It turns out the government's recent announcement of a 'Billion-Dollar Better Roads Blitz To Fix Our Regional Roads' actually slashes country road repairs to less than a third of what has been undertaken by past governments.

Then there's Treasurer Jaclyn Symes promise to Victoria's CFA and VICSES volunteers of a $70m rolling fleet replacement program, the doubling of the Volunteer Emergency Services Equipment Program to $62m, and $30m extra for training.

Turns out Ms Symes' 2025-26 budget fails to mention this funding. When quizzed on the missing allocations the govern-ment told us it was in the 2024-25 budget update, as a line item for "supporting our emergency services and volunteers". The problem is the allocation leaves the door open for the govern-ment to spend the cash on any emergency service, from triple-0 Victoria to the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria and others.

Premier Allan keeps telling Victorians "every dollar" of her new $1.623bn emergency services tax will be spent on emergency services, without also explaining those services were already being funded by taxpayers.

Every volunteer knows the government is simply rebadging the current fire services property levy as an emergency services and volunteers fund to pull in an extra $590m in tax to help pay a $7.3bn interest bill on $155bn of net debt. As Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien says "it's always prudent to look at what Labor does, not what it says".

urn:contentItem:6FGH-NY83-RT9B-453J-00000-00Gippsland wildlife populations recovering from Black Summer devastation face new fire threat2025-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisGippsland wildlife populations recovering from Black Summer devastation face new fire threat

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Ian Royall

Wildlife carers fear a large burn-off planned in the state's east will harm native animal populations still recovering from the Black Summer fires five years ago.

A burn-off is scheduled this week for 2660 hectares in the Nicholson River valley, north of Bairnsdale in Gippsland.

But wildlife rescuers say that injured koalas and kangaroos that were saved and rehabilitated back into bushland now face a new threat from the blaze.

And it comes after another Forest Fire Management burn-off in a neighbouring valley burnt out of control last month.

Susie Pulis, from the Waterholes Wildlife Sanctuary located just south of the fire zone, called for a pause and a review of the burn-off.

"We need to look after the wildlife that's there. I don't feel safe and I certainly don't trust them to burn safely.''

Ms Pulis said wildlife populations in the area were still recovering.

"We went through the fires five years ago and now we see this - it's really worrying.

"I hope this doesn't get out of control.

"The habitat is extremely young - five years only of growth.''

Forest Fire Management announced it would burn off 26,404 hectares in the coming five to 10 years around the upper reaches of the Nicholson River in the Yowen-Burrun State Forest.

The Herald Sun was told the initial target area would be just 300 to 500 hectares but this week's announcement was for an area more than five times that.

Ms Pulis said the timing of the burn-off also meant many animals such as snakes were hunkering down for the winter and would be caught by the flames.

"We have some many species here including the Powerful Owl. The impact is immeasurable.

"It is far too soon to burn such critical habitat for bush fire survivors, their off spring and the sanctuary's released animals.''

FFMV regional manager Peter Brick said the area was impacted by uncontrollable fires in 2020 and in 2007.

"To reduce the risk of this happening again it is critical we seize every available opportunity.

"The Marthavale - Barmouth Spur fuel reduction burn will be delivered over a five to 10-year period to provide community and environmental protection against bushfire.

"Reducing bushfire risk to Victorian communities and the environment is our priority and we do it through the delivery of low-intensity fire, mechanical treatments and responding to emergencies when they occur."

But Shelly Nundra from Gippsland Community Fire Watch described the planned burn-off as "obscene".

"We just can't trust FFMV to light fires and contain them after the recent Wonnangatta escaped plan burn debacle.''

Last month fires raged for days in nearby Wonnangatta Valley, triggered by Forest Fire Management burns that got out of control.

Ahmad Gharabli with Carlos Reyes in Modiin and Alice Chancellor in Jerusalem

April 30th, 2025 ( International Business Times Australia - Delivered by Newstex )

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned on Wednesday that rapidly spreading wildfires near Jerusalem could reach the city, as he declared the situation a "national emergency".

Thick plumes of smoke billowed above highways near Jerusalem as firefighters rushed to control wildfires that have injured several people and prompted the military to deploy troops to help the firefighters.

Israel's Magen David Adom rescue agency reported that hundreds of civilians were at risk from the worst brushfires in years.

MDA said it had provided treatment to around 23 people, 13 of whom were taken to hospital, the majority suffering from smoke inhalation and burns.

Among them were two pregnant women and two infants under a year old, it added.

It said the alert level had been raised to the highest tier.

Speaking from near the city of Modiin as fires burnt on a nearby hillside, resident Yuval Aharoni, 40, said: "It's just very sad because we knew the weather, we kind of knew that would happen and still we feel like they weren't ready enough with the big planes that can drop large amounts of water."

Netanyahu meanwhile warned that "the western wind can push the fire easily towards the outskirts of (Jerusalem) -- and even into the city itself".

"We need to bring as many fire engines as possible and create firebreaks well beyond the current fire lines... We are now in a national emergency, not just a local one," he added in a video statement.

"The priority right now is defending Jerusalem," he said.

Police closed the main Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway and evacuated residents along the route as brushfires broke out again in an area ravaged by blazes a week ago. Communities housing thousands of people have been cleared out.

"A lot of police arrived, a lot of firefighters, but it didn't really help. The fire had already completely taken over the whole area here," student Yosef Aaron told AFP, speaking on the side of a highway with flames visible in the distance.

Fire chief Eyal Caspi warned at a televised press conference that "our aircraft can't do anything right now due to the weather conditions... Our goal is to save lives".

"We are apparently facing the largest fire in Israel in a decade."

The police said on X that they had deployed in force around the Jerusalem-Tel Aviv highway and the Jerusalem Hills, asking the public to "avoid travelling to the area".

An AFP journalist at the scene earlier Wednesday said the blaze was sweeping through wooded areas near the main road between Latrun and Bet Shemesh, and that helicopters were working to extinguish the flames.

Soldiers arrived on the scene mid-afternoon, with many drivers abandoning their vehicles to flee the fire.

Communities located about 30 kilometres (19 miles) west of Jerusalem were evacuated, Israeli media reported, airing images of firefighting teams battling fierce flames.

National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir hinted that arson could be behind the fires, as police said they had arrested a resident of east Jerusalem who was caught "attempting to set fire to a field in the southern part of the city".

But there was no official declaration directly linking the two.

Ben Gvir said police would arrest anyone "involved in arson terror", while also monitoring for unrest.

MDA said ambulance teams had been positioned near communities close to the fires and were ready to provide medical treatment and assist residents.

High temperatures and strong winds have allowed the fires in wooded areas to spread quickly, prompting evacuations from at least five communities, the police said in a statement.

Ben Gvir, who oversees Israel's fire department, visited the affected area, which is prone to wildfires at this time of year.

In a video statement, he said work was being done to bring more assistance to the affected areas and evacuate stranded civilians.

The Foreign Ministry has contacted nearby countries including Greece, Cyprus, Croatia, Italy and Bulgaria for assistance, according to a statement.

Netanyahu's office said three aircraft would arrive soon from Italy and Croatia to help fight the fires.

"The decision is aimed at reallocating forces to deal with the fire... and preparing for the worsening weather conditions according to forecasts," a statement said.

urn:contentItem:6FDD-3CB3-S55N-72W4-00000-00Where you might see more smoke in the Ballarat region this month2025-03-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisWhere you might see more smoke in the Ballarat region this monthAdam Spencer

The CFA is also issuing a number of private burn-off permits.

Planned burning will ramp up in the Ballarat region in the next 10 days, as Forest Fire Management crews work to reduce the risk of bushfires.

A number of planned burns will take place in state forests, parks and reserves around Ballarat, Smythesdale, Daylesford, Trentham, Macedon, Greendale and Blackwood while the weather is favourable.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Deputy Chief Fire Officer Jason Hellyer said planned burns are a key component to reducing hee size, intensity, and impact of bushfires.

"Reducing fuels such as grass, leaves, bark, shrubs and small fallen branches means fires are less intense, slower to spread, and safer for firefighters to control," Mr Hellyer said.

"Autumn is generally the best time of the year to undertake planned burns as the weather is more stable and fire behaviour is manageable and predictable."

For updates on planned burns in the region visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au/ .

It comes as the CFA begins to issue a small number of "schedule 13" private burn-off permits to farmers in the Ballarat area.

District 15 Assistant Chief Fire Officer Lachlan Redman said the permits would mainly be used by landowners, but does not mean Victorians can burn off piles of trees and branches are able to without a permit.

"Private burn-offs are a vital part of farming practices. Burning of crop stubble is often needed to kill off weeds and reduce pests," Mr Redman said.

"Should we see fire danger elevated due to a change in weather, wind and temperature, the issuing of the Schedule 13 permits will be withdrawn, revoked or suspended based on their status.

"While some permits are being issued, residents must still be aware that the Fire Danger Period is still in place, and no burning off is to occur unless people have received permission."

Each permit issued will have several conditions stated that landowners must comply with when undertaking burning activity.

More information can be found at firepermits.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:6FYN-PNC3-SC5B-K0NC-00000-00'Chaos' as fire cuts bite2025-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3'Chaos' as fire cuts bitePETER HUNT

Victoria's fire and emergency services have been thrown into turmoil after Treasurer Jaclyn Symes published a gazette that revealed a $165m cut to CFA, FRV and VicSES budgets.

At 4.52pm last Friday Ms Symes issued a government gazette outlining how the new $1.55bn emergency services levy will be distributed across agencies in 2025-26 - including those within government departments.

According to the gazette, $312m or 90 per cent of the CFA's "Forecast Funding Requirements" for 2025-26 will be covered by the tax. When combined with the government's statutory obligation of 10 per cent, the CFA's total 2025-26 budget rises to $328m - down from $370m in 2023-24.

Ms Symes' office told the Opposition in March the 2024-25 figures were unavailable, but did supply the 2023-24 allocations instead.

The gazette also reveals VicSES' budget has been slashed from $85.2m in 2023-24 to $76.8m 2025-26.

Fire Rescue Victoria is facing the steepest cut, with funding set to drop from $961.4m last financial year to $846.4m in 2025-26.

Opposition emergency services spokesman Danny O'Brien said the figures "reveal the lie behind this new tax - it was never about supporting emergency services, it was always about the government trying to plug holes in the budget".

When questioned about the cuts this week, Ms Symes office said there were no cuts and "these incorrect claims are another example of repeated, deliberate misinformation by the Weekly Times.

"The gazetted figures are based on an estimated forecast of base funding and do not include all funding provided to emergency services." However, the publication of the gazette has left emergency services scrambling for answers. CFA sources said they were still waiting on clarification from Treasury.

Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria chief executive Adam Barnett said "it leaves CFA planning in chaos, unable to order new trucks and secure builders for stations". Even Forest Fire Management Victoria - responsible for bushfire response and fuel reduction on public land - has had its funding cut, from $431m in 2023-24 to $401m in 2025-26.

This compares with net earnings of $797 million on net sales of $7.5 billion for the full year 2020. Full year 2021 includes a total after-tax benefit of $81 million for special items. Weyerhaeuser Company has outlined its strategic goals aimed at enhancing shareholder value and operational efficiency. On the 4th of September 2025, Weyerhaeuser released presentation materials for investors, emphasizing its commitment to disciplined capital allocation and sustainable practices.

September 02: Weyerhaeuser Concludes Sale of Princeton Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Weyerhaeuser Company has completed the sale of its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group. This transaction, initially announced in May, includes the transfer of Weyerhaeuser's associated timber licenses in British Columbia, which are expected to be finalized in the coming months, subject to regulatory review and customary closing conditions.

As part of the sale, Weyerhaeuser received approximately $60 million USD upfront, with additional proceeds tied to the transfer of the timber licenses. The company has recognized a gain from the sale but anticipates a tax liability of about $11 million USD as a result of the transaction. This sale reflects Weyerhaeuser's ongoing strategy to optimize its operations and focus on its core business areas.

Established in 1900, Weyerhaeuser is among the largest private owners of timberlands worldwide, managing approximately 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and additional public timberlands in Canada. The company is recognized for its commitment to sustainability, operating all its timberlands in compliance with internationally recognized forestry standards. In 2024, Weyerhaeuser reported net sales of $7.1 billion and employed around 9,400 people globally.

The Gorman Group, a family-owned business founded in 1951, operates multiple divisions in Southern British Columbia and northern Washington state, employing about 900 individuals. The company is well-regarded for its high-value lumber products, particularly in the home finishing and renovation markets. The acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's mill aligns with Gorman Group's long-term strategy of enhancing its operational capabilities and market presence.

Weyerhaeuser's decision to divest its Princeton mill is part of a broader trend in the timber industry, where companies are reassessing their portfolios to focus on areas with higher growth potential.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 4 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

SECTION 9 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

9.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

urn:contentItem:6G65-4B83-RV0H-X0YW-00000-00Officers banned from emergency duties2025-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisRural57Officers banned from emergency dutiesJodie Bruton

Border officers have been indispensable in natural disasters.

Almost three years ago, fisheries officers were mustered from throughout Victoria to help out with monumental floods in the Goulburn Valley.

With specialist skills and experience and the right boats for the job, it was not the first time they had been called out to a natural disaster.

Recently retired Wodonga-based senior fisheries officer Greg Sharp, who was the operations lead for the Victorian Fisheries Authority based in the incident control centre during the 2022 spring floods, said the rain caused the rivers to rise rapidly, leading to major flooding at Shepparton and surrounds.

"Our boat crews provided round-the-clock support to Ambulance Victoria and Goulburn Valley Health, and relief agencies - Salvation Army, Society of St Vincent de Paul - delivering food and emergency medicine to householders stranded by flood waters in and around Shepparton and Tatura," he said.

"Fisheries officers also assisted with wildlife management in the weeks after the floods receded, assisting professional shooters to euthanise stranded wildlife otherwise facing a slow, lingering death ...."

Mr Sharp said fisheries officers also provided water-borne transport services during and after the January 2020 Mallacoota bushfires, which destroyed 123 houses and 65 sheds.

"In the immediate aftermath of the 2020 fires, the only road into Mallacoota was utterly impassable, littered with debris and lined with scorched trees ready to shed limbs at the slightest breeze," he said.

"It was therefore necessary for fisheries officers - in Kevlacat patrol vessels - to ferry supplies, personnel and essential equipment into the town by sea from Lakes Entrance. There was so much smoke in the air, flying in was not an option. Aircraft were grounded."

Mr Sharp said officers were kept busy landing supplies and Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters onto beaches in the remote Croajingolong National Park via Mallacoota Inlet.

"Not even the Navy could get in," he said.

"Our vessels provided the necessary shuttle service between offshore vessels and onshore landing points, whether they be the wharf, a jetty or one of the beaches."

Awarded with a National Emergency Medal for his role as a fisheries officer in the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires, Mr Sharp said fisheries officers had a long history of helping out in major natural disasters since the 1950s.

He said it was unfathomable that the Victorian Fisheries Authority (VFA) had stripped its officers of their duties to "respond to an emergency" as of Friday, June 13.

It comes amid statewide controversy over the government's new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund and whether it would deliver value for rural ratepayers, or subsidise Fire Rescue Victoria service provision to urban areas and Melbourne.

The VFA replaced the state's 73 fisheries officer jobs with 36 engagement officers.

In May, retired fisheries manager Mike Hosking said inland fisheries officers would be impacted by having fewer staff on the ground for joint operations .

"It's all about the state government being broke and needing every department reduced by 40 per cent," he said. "It's a crying shame; we've spent so much time bringing fisheries back from the brink."

Former Chief Commissioner of Victoria Police Kel Glare, his Community Advocacy Alliance and more than 12,900 Victorians have so far signed an online petition for an inquiry into the fisheries authority because the restructure had gone ahead without that risk assessment.

Mr Sharp said a rumoured merger of the VFA with the Game Management Authority might salvage some enforcement clout from the sacking of almost half the state's fisheries officers, but it would not make up for a ban on the remaining officers responding to emergencies.

He said that while there were some synergies between the organisations, staff numbers had been decimated. "It's smoke and mirrors," he said. "What few fisheries officers who were left would then be expected to be running around the mountains chasing spotlighters."

urn:contentItem:6FJF-HS63-RX5F-B362-00000-00'Prepare to leave': warning issued as blaze south of Daylesford continues to burn2025-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexis'Prepare to leave': warning issued as blaze south of Daylesford continues to burnAdam Spencer

A Watch and Act warning has been issued.

Residents living near a bushfire south of Daylesford are being urged to prepare to leave and watch for changing conditions as firefighters continue to attack the blaze in the Hepburn Regional Park.

A Watch and Act message has been issued for the Musk Vale, Sailors Hill and Sailors Falls areas by Forest Fire Management Victoria on Saturday, April 12.

An Advice message has also been issued for Borlands, Bullarto South, Daylesford, Korweinguboora, Leonards Hill, Paddy Point, Woodburn.

Watch and Act - Bushfire - Prepare to Leave

Issued (Saturday) at 4:59 PM.

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Musk Vale, Sailors Falls, Sailors Hill.

It is strongly recommended you Prepare to Leave.

There is a bushfire in Hepburn Regional Park near Black Jack Track that is not yet under control.

The bushfire is travelling slowly from Black Jack Track in a south-easterly direction.

Aircraft is slowing the spread of the fire, however fire activity remains elevated.

This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch & Act - Prepare to Leave issued at 2.37pm.

Prepare to Leave immediately. Leave as soon as you are ready, as roads will become busy as people leave.

What you should do:

Monitor the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.

Protect yourself and your family.

If you are not prepared, leave now. Don't wait until it is too late - leave early.

If you are away from home, do not return.

If you are leaving, pack:

Cash

Clothing for three days

Medicine for three days

Phone and chargers

Toiletries

Important documents

Meaningful items and photos

Pet essentials, including leash and carriers.

Check on your neighbours if it is safe.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe.

Where to go:

Friends or family away from the fire.

Consider roads may become busy closer to the time of impact.

Do not enter Hepburn Regional Park because you will place yourself in danger.

A Relief Centre is open at the Newlyn Recreation Reserve at 2745 Midland Highway, Newlyn

Impacts in your area:

Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.

Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.

Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.

This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 8.00 pm or as the situation changes.

Advice - Bushfire - Stay Informed

Issued Today at 3:56 PM.

This Advice message is being issued for Borlands, Bullarto South, Daylesford, Korweinguboora, Leonards Hill, Paddy Point, Woodburn.

There is a bushfire in Hepburn Regional Park near Black Jack Track that is not yet under control.

The bushfire is travelling from Black Jack Track in a south-easterly direction towards Sailors Hill.

There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

What you should do:

Monitor weather conditions and warnings.

Review your fire survival plan.

If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.

Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.

A Relief Centre is open at the Newlyn Recreation Reserve at 2745 Midland Highway, Newlyn

Impacts in your area:

Firefighters are responding to this fire.

Aircraft are operating in the area.

Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.

This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/04/2025 08:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Aerial waterbombers are assisting in the fight against a bushfire in the Hepburn Regional Park, south of Daylesford on April 12, 2025. Picture by Kate Healy
