urn:contentItem:6FRS-TRJ3-RRJH-41V8-00000-00'It's money I haven't got': Farmers raise concerns about new levy2025-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisFront Page1'It's money I haven't got': Farmers raise concerns about new levyIsobel Cootes and Nieve Walton

The more Victorian farmers learn about a new emergency services levy, the more "they're starting to think, 'How the hell am I gonna pay that?'"

With some rural properties facing a $5000 rate hike because of the new levy, regional residents will be paying attention to Spring Street on May 13 when parliament returns.

The controversial Emergency Services and Volunteers Levy has faced backlash from councils, Rural Councils Victoria, the firefighters' union, and the Victorian Farmers Federation.

"They're not the sort that are normally all on the same page," Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien told The Courier. "That should tell the government that they've got this wrong."

The state government has proposed a 189 per cent increase in the variable component of the levy for primary production land from July 1.

The existing levy raises $1,033,000 per year.

The new levy is anticipated to raise an additional $610.9 million in the 2025/26 financial year, and a further $765 million in the following two years.

The new levy will pay for nine emergency services: the State Emergency Service (SES), Triple Zero, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria, the Country Fire Authority (CFA), and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV).

About 150 people attended a community forum last month in Beaufort about it, and on Tuesday night, it was a similar story at the Ascot Hall.

Clunes sheep farmer Stu Robinson was tasked with making sure the community knew about the levy and its implications. But, he said, even though it was being promoted as a volunteer support fund, it only benefited two such organisations.

A total of $50 million per year has been earmarked for CFA and SES.

"There's only two volunteer organisations in those nine bodies, that being the CFA and the SES," Mr Robinson said.

"Regions and towns won't see any of that, or very little of that money, come back. It's going to really impact our region.

Continued - page 7

Clunes farmer Stuart Robinson (left), alongside Graeme Ford, Ian Terrill, John Henderson-Drife and Phillip Wilson all have many concerns about the proposed new levy. Picture by Lachlan Bence

urn:contentItem:6G23-NBC3-RTGH-W2PF-00000-00Hundreds rally in Ballarat CBD calling to scrap the new ESVF levy2025-06-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisHundreds rally in Ballarat CBD calling to scrap the new ESVF levyIsobel Cootes

'The government is using it as a cash cow to retire debt.'

The hundreds of CFA sirens and car horns sounding along Sturt Street delivered the message loud and clear to the Victorian Government on Sunday: 'scrap the tax'.

It will not be able to escape the noise surrounding the divisive new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund (ESVF) levy anytime soon, and it will likely only ramp up ahead of next year's state election.

Ballarat got a taste, hosting the latest 'Not In Our Name' rally on June 15, with supporters, farmers and more than 50 CFA trucks from across the state taking to the city's streets in protest.

The rally travelled from Victoria Park to the CBD, before lapping Lake Wendouree, and passing by Member for Wendouree Juliana Addison and Member for Eureka Michaela Settle's offices along the way.

Messages like 'no farmers, no food, no future', 'scrap the tax', 'axe the tax', and 'burn the levy, not our wallets' adorned signs and vehicles.

Wimmera farmer Andrew Weidemann, one of the organisers behind the 'Not In Our Name' campaign, got to the rally's core message.

"The government is using it as a cash cow to retire debt," he said on the new levy.

"Every business owner, everybody that rents a house here in Ballarat, anybody that owns a house here is about to see their bill double.

"And every levy that I'm involved with at the national level has an oversight body, to make sure that the money is actually returned to where it was sourced from. That's not what we're seeing at the moment."

All ratepayers will pay substantially more under the new levy from July 1, which aims to raise $7 billion over the next four years, or $2.9 billion more than the previous levy would have.

State-wide, it's due to collect $1.62 billion in 2025-26 and $1.8 billion in each of the next three years, which will fund services including CFA, FRV, SES, Triple Zero Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

But analysis by ACM - publisher of this masthead - revealed FRV will consume up to 70 per cent of the funding each year .

United Firefighters Union delegate and FRV Lucas firefighter, Luke Shearer, dubbed the new levy a "horror".

"The government are trying to plug a hole in their budget. They have massively overspent, and they are using emergency service workers to try and cover it, to use our names to put a tax on people, and wrecking the name of emergency services in Victoria," he said.

"Victorians aren't stupid. They're going to start getting their rates notice, both metropolitan Melbourne and regional Victoria, in September, and they're not going to be happy when they see what's happening."

The new fund, which is replacing the cheaper Fire Services Property Levy, has been met with widespread fury from rural residents and councils, who feel disproportionately affected by the new tax.

But it will have wider ramifications for the more than 60,000 properties in the Ballarat municipality , with almost $6 million more predicted to be collected next financial year.

The calculated average increase in ESVF payments for City of Ballarat ratepayers will be: 34 per cent for residential properties, 72 per cent for commercial properties, and 46 per cent for industrial properties.

And primary producers were set to be hit with a 148 per cent increase before Premier Jacinta Allan announced a one-year reprieve last month, with farmers to pay the old rate for the 2025-26 financial year.

Mayor Tracey Hargreaves said the new levy would "absolutely affect every single person" in the state.

"The City of Ballarat has been really strong in that advocacy against the levy since day one. We're just trying to do the best for our community," she said.

"We're aware of the effects on Ballarat, but as you can see, there are people here coming from all parts of Victoria, all with the same message that this is just an unfair burden on communities."

The ESVF will be collected by councils across the state, on behalf of the government, as part of rates notices.

There had been calls for municipalities to refuse to collect the levy, but councillor Hargreaves explained why that would not be possible in Ballarat or elsewhere.

"If people decide not to pay the levy component, that shortfall will have to be made up by local council's budget," she said.

"So this absolutely will divert really necessary funds away from our core services, and that's on top of the administrative burden that we're already going to be facing collecting it."

Affected by this story? There is help available. You can phone Lifeline on 13 11 14.

urn:contentItem:6DTB-P7N3-RT6M-638P-00000-00Rain interrupts strategic backburning operations on the Attunga Forest fire2025-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:38ZLexisNexisRain interrupts strategic backburning operations on the Attunga Forest fireEmma Downey

Light rain on Thursday evening, January 2, hampered strategic backburning on the Attunga State Forest bushfire, but the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) aims to have the incident under control by Friday.

The RFS has set up a new bush fire information point at Northgate shopping centre in front of Coles supermarket as backburning operations increase the level of smoke across Tamworth.

RFS manager for community risk for the North West Area Command, Shellie Smyth, said the latest bushfire information point will operate between 11am and 6pm on Friday, January 3, and provide "greater exposure" to the local community impacted by the fire.

"Our community engagement team members will be available to provide any assistance or give information to the public that is concerned about the fires," she said.

"The bush fire information point at Moore Creek station on Thursday, January 2, was held off the back of a really successful community meeting the night before, so we're feeling quite comfortable the community is well informed about the situation.

"Moving into town widens our access to the public, enabling us to provide a greater number of community members with any advice or guidance they might need, particularly with backburning operations' smoke coming into Tamworth."

The RFS has also deployed field officers to undertake door-knocking to provide additional information to local fire-affected communities.

Ms Smyth said up to five millimetres fell across the Attunga fire ground late yesterday, making conditions "pretty slippery and risky for our teams".

"They were back out on the job today, and will continue to strengthen containment lines around the Attunga fire throughout today," she said.

"The rain did prevent some of the backburning operations we had planned; however, the RFS continued to prepare properties around Stirling Road for the backburns, which will continue today.

"We will continue to strengthen containment lines around properties in the Stirling Road area and also in other sectors, particularly on the eastern side of the fire."

Ms Smyth said the Attunga fire is holding steady at around 610 hectares in size.

Some support crews head home Some of the out-of-area crews from the Greater Sydney region will start to head home on Saturday, January 4, while those remaining will continue to support local crews.

A small fire, two-hectare fire occurred along Barry Road at Hanging Rock on Thursday evening, however Ms Smyth said the RFS drew on resources working on Bowling Alley Point fire, now under control, to quickly respond and contain the blaze.

Ms Smyth said lightning strikes associated with recent storm activity passing through the area had been responsible for igniting the majority of fires across the region in the past week.
